titleStmt.title: Hypoxia-reoxygenation enhances murine afferent arteriolar vasoconstriction by angiotensin II

affiliation.orgName: Univ. of California and Veterans Affairs San Diego Healthcare System

analytic.title: Hypoxia-reoxygenation enhances murine afferent arteriolar vasoconstriction by angiotensin II

biblStruct.note: Submitted 15 May 2017; accepted in final form 24 October 2017

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

p.s: We tested the hypothesis that hypoxia-reoxygenation (H/R) augments vasoreactivity to angiotensin II (ANG II).
In particular, we compared an in situ live kidney slice model with isolated afferent arterioles (C57Bl6 mice) to assess the impact of tubules on microvessel response.
Hematoxylin and eosin staining was used to estimate slice viability.
Arterioles in the slices were located by differential interference contrast microscopy, and responses to vasoactive substances were assessed.
Cytosolic calcium transients and NADPH oxidase (NOX) mRNA expression were studied in isolated afferent arterioles.
SOD activity was measured in live slices.
Both experimental models were subjected to control and H/R treatment (60 min).
Slices were further analyzed after 30-, 60-, and 90-min hypoxia followed by 10-or 20-min reoxygenation (H/R).
H/R resulted in enhanced necrotic tissue damage compared with control conditions.

To characterize the slice model, we applied ANG II (10 Ϫ7 M), norepinephrine (NE; 10 Ϫ5 M), endothelin-1 (ET-1; 10 Ϫ7 M), and ATP (10 Ϫ4 M), reducing the initial diameter to 44.5 Ϯ 2.8, 50.0 Ϯ 2.2, 45.3 Ϯ 2.6, and 74.1 Ϯ 1.8%, respectively.
H/R significantly increased the ANG II response compared with control in live slices and in isolated afferent arterioles, although calcium transients remained similar.
TEMPOL incubation prevented the H/R effect on ANG II responses.
H/R significantly increased NOX2 mRNA expression in isolated arterioles.
SOD activity was significantly decreased after H/R.
Enhanced arteriolar responses after H/R occurred independently from the surrounding tissue, indicating no influence of tubules on vascular function in this model.
The mechanism of increased ANG II response after H/R might be increased oxidative stress and increased calcium sensitivity of the contractile apparatus.
Acute kidney injury (AKI), the rapid deterioration of normal kidney function, poses a significant and rising clinical problem in already hospitalized or severely ill patients.
Highly relevant in the pathogenesis of multiple forms of AKI is a preceding event of renal ischemia-reperfusion injury (IRI).
Renal IRI is characterized by a transient reduced kidney perfusion and accompanying hypoxia.
The exact mechanisms by which hypoxia/reoxygenation (H/R) compromise renal blood flow and glomerular filtration rate (GFR) as well as tissue repair remain unknown.
Experimental animal studies demonstrate proximal tubular damage by H/R, ultimately leading to necrosis, apoptosis (32), and damage to the renal vasculature (4,5).
Moreover, H/R perturbs homeostasis of utilization of oxygen, reduces NO bioavailability, and increases reactive oxygen species (ROS), which all disrupt renal microvascular function (1,9,18).
Previous studies almost exclusively focused on the influence of H/R on overall kidney function or tubular damage.

However, the effect of H/R on renal microvessel reactivity is poorly understood and lacks thorough investigation, even though profound knowledge of vasoreactivity is crucial for improving the treatment of AKI.

Using isolated interlobar arteries as well as afferent arterioles, Kaufmann et al. (23) showed that 1 h of hypoxia in the presence of norepinephrine (NE) followed by 10 min of reoxygenation increases angiotensin II (ANG II) responses in vitro.
This observation suggests that H/R can either be a result of vessel dysfunction or exert influence on vessel function.
Therefore, it is of interest how the surrounding tubular tissue modulates vascular tone under H/R conditions.
Vasoactive substances released from damaged tubules may increase ANG II induced constriction (33).
To date, thorough in situ investigation of cortical microvessels has been hampered by the lack of an appropriate experimental model.

Recently, Crawford et al. (10) introduced an innovative model of living kidney slices, with which we aim to investigate the function of the afferent arterioles after H/R while they are surrounded by intact tubules.
This model opens the door to investigating renal microvessels with its surrounding tissue, where tubulovascular cross talk is of considerable importance (11).

We hypothesize that H/R leads to enhanced afferent arteriolar tone and that the surrounding tubules contribute to the disruption of renal microvascular function and thus to reduced renal blood flow in AKI.

We set out to validate this new in situ model for cortical microvessels by analyzing the afferent arteriolar response to vasoactive substances including ANG II, NE, endothelin-1 (ET-1), and nitric oxide synthase (NOS) inhibition.

Since ANG II is an important renal vasoconstrictor and ANG II responses increase after H/R in isolated arteries (17,23,34,36,44), we employed this in situ model to test our hypothesis and to characterize the impact of H/R on ANG II responses in renal microvessels.
Various periods of hypoxia and reoxygenation were applied to analyze the effect on arteriolar function.
We document increased vasoreactivity to ANG II following H/R, which may constitute an important component in IRI of the kidney.

To test the importance of adjacent tubules and to dissect the mechanisms by which H/R influences vasoreactivity, we compared the ANG II response of arterioles in situ with that of isolated arterioles.
All experiments were performed and approved in accordance with the regulations of the Office for Health and Social Matters of Berlin (Berlin, Germany).
Male C57BL6 mice (25-30 g) were purchased from Forschungseinrichtungen fuer Experimentelle Medizin, Charité-Universitätsmedizin Berlin Germany.
Preparation of live kidney slices.
Tissue slices were prepared as previously described with minor modifications (7,10).

Briefly, after cervical dislocation of mice, kidneys were removed and immediately transferred to ice-cold physiological saline solution (PSS; pH 7.4) bubbled with carbogen gas mixture (control, 95% O 2-5% CO2; Linde, Leuna, Germany).
PSS contained the following (mM): 119 NaCl, 4.7 KCl, 1.2 KH2PO4, 1.2 MgSO4, 6.1 glucose, 25 NaHCO3, and 2.5 CaCl2 (Carl Roth, Karlsruhe, Germany).
The kidneys were decapsulated and affixed onto the slicing block of a VT1200S vibratome (Leica, Nussloch Germany).
The kidney was submerged into ice-cold PSS during slice preparation.
Two-hundred-micrometer-thick coronal kidney slices were cut, and slices were transferred to purpose-built holding chambers containing PSS bubbled with carbogen and prewarmed to 37°C.
The slices were used for experiments within 3 h after preparation.

Slices were either transferred to a Whitley H135 hypoxic chamber (1% O 2, equilibrated PSS, 37°C; Meintrup dws Laborgeräte, Lähden-Holte, Germany) or kept at control conditions (37°C, PSS, carbogen bubbled) for a defined time span.
Determination of viability of live kidney slices.

Live kidney slices (200 m) underwent hypoxic and control treatment and were fixed with 4% formaldehyde after 30-and 90-min hypoxic gas treatment (1% O 2-5% CO2-94% N2) followed by reoxygenation of 10 min with carbogen or control condition with carbogen.
Slices were embedded in paraffin, and 2.5-m tissue sections were obtained.
Tissue sections were deparaffinized and subsequently used for hematoxylin and eosin staining.
Slides were visualized, and histological damage was assessed by an experimenter blinded to group allocation.

Damage was analyzed in at least five independent experiments per group, and tissue sections were classified into three groups (healthy, mildly, and severely damaged) since established scoring does not apply for live slices.
Functional experiments and analysis.
Live kidney slices were secured in an open-bath chamber using a purpose-built platinum slice anchor and transferred to the stage of an Axio Observer.Z1 microscope (Zeiss, Jena, Germany).
Kidney slices were continuously superfused (4 ml/min, 2-ml bath volume) with PSS, bubbled with 95% O 2-5% CO2, and maintained at 37°C.
Afferent arterioles in proximity to their glomerulus were chosen for functional experiments and differential interference contrast images were captured through a Zeiss ϫ63 water immersion objective.

The identification of afferent arterioles followed a threefold criteria: 1) they could be traced until they encountered their respective glomeruli, 2) they displayed a continuous vascular smooth muscle cell wall structure in contrast to efferent arterioles, and 3) their baseline diameter was ~8 m.
Images of afferent arteriole diameter were collected every 5 s ( ϭ 1 frame) by an attached Moticam 2000 camera and recorded by Motic Images Plus 2.0 software (Motic Germany, Wetzlar, Germany).

After baseline recording for 60 s, live kidney slices were superfused with ANG II (10 Ϫ7 M), norepinephrine (NE; 10 Ϫ5 M), endothelin-1 (ET-1; 10 Ϫ7 M), ATP (10 Ϫ4 M), or N G -nitro-L-arginine methyl ester (L-NAME; 10 Ϫ4 M).
In the case of L-NAME, slices were superfused with gassed-PSS-L-NAME solution 15 min before the start of the experiment and thus before baseline measurements.
Potential changes in diameter were recorded for 240 s.
Subsequently, a KCl (100 mM) solution was added to the bath to confirm the viability of the investigated arteriole.
Only arterioles showing complete constriction were used for analysis.
Slices that underwent hypoxia were subjected to a 10 or 20 min reoxygenation period before they were transferred to the bath chamber.
To construct concentration-response curves (CRCs), the kidney slices were treated with ANG II (10 Ϫ10 to 10 Ϫ6 M) with 3-min intervals between applications.
Each vessel was used for one experiment only.
The CRC served as the basis for the chosen ANG II concentration in the following experiments.
Time-series analysis of live kidney slice experiments was carried out using the public domain software ImageJ (National Institutes of Health, https://imagej.nih.gov/ij/).
For each experiment, the site of strongest constriction was chosen for analysis.
The diameter of the lumen of the afferent arterioles was measured in every frame for the entire experiment.
By determining the baseline, each arteriole acted as its own control.
All subsequent diameter measurements were calculated and expressed as a percentage of the corresponding baseline value.
The mean of the baseline data was set to 100%.
The maximum constriction in each experiment was identified, averaged, and plotted.
Renal arteriole preparation.
Preparation of renal arterioles from mice was performed as previously published (39).

Briefly, the mice were euthanized by cervical dislocation, and thin slices (0.5-1 mm) of the kidney were cut and immediately placed in a dissection dish containing ice-cold DMEM (GIBCO, Darmstadt, Germany) and 0.1% bovine serum albumin (albumin; Carl Roth, Karlsruhe, Germany).
The afferent arterioles attached to their glomeruli were isolated manually at 4°C with sharpened forceps under a stereomicroscope.
Hypoxic conditioning.
A purpose-built hypoxia chamber was designed to perform hypoxia experiments in arterioles.
For experiments under hypoxia, 95% N 2-5% CO2 (Linde) was used.
With the use of an oxygen sensor, measurements in the purpose-built hypoxia chamber showed a PO2 of ~3-4 mmHg, with 0% O2 in the gas.
Thus PO2 values for isolated arterioles and arterioles in situ were similar under hypoxia.
DMEM was bubbled with 95% N2-5% CO2 for 10 min before addition of 0.1% albumin.
The isolated arterioles were placed at a dissection dish containing the equilibrated DMEM and immediately put into the chamber for 1-h treatment under continuous nitrogen influx at room temperature.
Arterioles under normoxic conditions and with unconditioned DMEM ϩ 0.1% albumin served as controls.
Renal arteriole perfusion.
Afterward, arterioles were transferred to a thermo-controlled chamber and mounted with glass pipettes in a perfusion system.
The procedure was described by our group in detail before (35).
One plastic tube connected to a reservoir provided DMEM ϩ 1% albumin perfusion solution into the opening end of the arteriole.
The arterioles were perfused at 37°C with a pressure of 100 mmHg (corresponding to a flow of ~50 nl/min) in the pressure head.
In all experiments, the perfusion was achieved within 2 h after mice were euthanized.
Arteriolar reactivity to ANG II.
After a 10-min adaptation to 37°C, KCl (100 mM) was applied to the chamber as a bolus for 10 s.
Only the afferent arterioles showing a complete constriction response were used in the subsequent experiments.
A baseline of the luminal diameter was recorded before ANG II treatment.
The afferent arterioles were treated with ANG II (10 Ϫ12 to 10 Ϫ6 M; Sigma-Aldrich, Munich, Germany) with 2-min intervals between applications to construct CRCs.
In experiments using the superoxide dismutase mimetic 4-hydroxy-TEMPO (TEMPOL), this substance (10 Ϫ4 M) was present in the bath solution during the whole experiment.
Experiments were recorded as serial digital pictures (1/s during the last 15 s of each ANG II concentration) by a digital camera attached to the microscope (Moticam2).

In all series, the average diameter from the five mea-F431 HYPOXIA-REOXYGENATION INCREASES VASOCONSTRICTION surements of each concentration of ANG II was used for statistical analysis of steady-state responses.
Each vessel was used for one experiment only.
Analysis of ANG II receptor and NADPH oxidase mRNA expression.
Renal arterioles were isolated using the previously established and published iron perfusion technique (28).
The magnetically isolated vascular structures were then subjected to either carbogen or hypoxia (60-min ϩ 10-min reoxygenation) treatment.
Vessels were subsequently used for the analysis of mRNA expression.

RNA was isolated using the RNA-Bee RNA Isolation Reagent (AMS Biotechnology, Abingdon, UK) and reverse transcribed with a High Capacity cDNA-Synthesis Kit and random hexamer-nucleotides (Applied Biosystems, Darmstadt, Germany) according to the manufacturer's protocol.
Quantitative PCR analysis was performed with a StepOnePlus device (Applied Biosystems, Foster City, CA) using SYBR Green for fluorescent detection of DNA generated during PCR.
Experiments were performed in triplicate.
The expression levels of mRNA were normalized to housekeeping gene RPL13A by the ⌬C t method.
Primers (Eurofins, Ebersberg, Germany) that bridge at least one intron were designed for PCR amplification based on published sequences for mice (Table 1).
Quantification of the cytosolic calcium concentration in isolated afferent arterioles.
The membrane-permeable fluorescent calcium indicator fura 2 acetoxymethyl ester (fura 2-AM, 10 Ϫ5 M) was added to the bath solution.
Perfused afferent arterioles were hence loaded for 40 min at room temperature.
Subsequently, ANG II, in a concentration range of 10 Ϫ12 to 10 Ϫ6 M, was added to the bath solution in 2-min intervals.
Fura 2 fluorescence images were captured from 470 to 550 nm (excitation: 340 and 380 nm, respectively; VisiView Software, Visitron Systems, Munich, Germany).
Images were taken at 5-s intervals, while the last 20 s of each ANG II concentration was used for further analysis.
Metamorph software (Molecular Devices, Silicon Valley, CA) was applied for the analysis for 340/380 nm ratio of fura 2 fluorescence.
The data are presented in relative values to the control situation.
Measurement of SOD activity in live kidney slices.
Live kidney slices were collected after control and H/R (30-20 and 90-20) conditions and were homogenized using a FastPrep FP120 (Thermo Scientific, Darmstadt, Germany).
SOD activity was determined using a superoxide dismutase assay kit (No. 706002; Cayman Chemical) following the protocol of the manufacturer.

The assay measures all three types of SOD and defines one unit of SOD as the amount of enzyme needed to exhibit 50% dismutation of the superoxide radicals generated by xanthine oxidase and hypoxanthine at 25°C.
The SOD activity is given as unit per milligrams of protein isolated from live kidney slices.
Protein content was measured using a NanoDrop 2000 (Thermo Scientific).
Pharmacological agents.
The following drugs were used: ANG II, NE, ET-1, ATP, L-NAME, and TEMPOL (all purchased from Sigma-Aldrich, Hamburg, Germany).
Statistical analysis.
Statistical analyses were performed using Statistics Software "R" (The R Project for Statistical Computing, http:// www.r-project.org/) and GraphPad Prism software version 5.0.
Data in the graphs are presented as means Ϯ SE.
For live kidney slices, the normal distribution of the analyzed groups was verified using the D'Agostino Pearson test, and two-group comparisons were analyzed by the Mann-Whitney test.
For isolated afferent arterioles, Brunner's test was used (The R Project for Statistical Computing, http://www.
r-project.org/).
The Mann-Whitney Rank Sum test served for post hoc comparisons.
The EC50 was calculated and the statistical test (Mann-Whitney test) was performed by using SigmaPlot 13.0 (Systat Software, Erkrath, Germany).
If applicable, the analysis of independent groups was performed with one-way ANOVA.
Dunnett's test was used as post hoc test for multiple group comparisons with the control group.
Tukey's test was used as post hoc test for multiple group comparisons excluding the control group.
P Ͻ 0.05 was considered significant.
The data are presented as relative values (i.e., percentage of the initial diameter).
Analyzing live kidney slices is feasible for up to 90 min.
We found no detectable changes in histological patterns following 30 and 90 min of control treatment (Fig. 1A).
Mild damage of live kidney slice tissue was found after 30 min of H/R, depicted by few localized necrotic areas and fading of single nuclei (Fig. 1B).
Following 90 min of H/R, we found mild and severe (Fig. 1C) necrotic damage.
Treating slices for 120 min resulted in severe tissue damage.
Here, carbogen-and H/R-treated slices showed disintegration of the tissue.
Figure 1, A-C, illustrates the applied pattern to classify healthy, mildly damaged, and severely damaged kidney slices.
ANG II, NE, ET-1, and ATP induce vasoconstriction in afferent arterioles.
For a detailed characterization of afferent arterioles in the new in situ system, we tested the response to physiologically important vasoactive substances.
ANG II, NE, and ET-1, all potent constrictors of afferent arterioles, were applied in a single concentration to the bath solution.
Depicted in Fig. 2, A and B, is a cut-out of a kidney slice and the representative ANG II-evoked response of an afferent arteriole (change in afferent arteriole diameter).
Initially, the stability of the baseline diameter was verified for the approximate length of the experiment (20 min; n ϭ 6).
For further experiments, the baseline diameter was measured for each arteriole for 60 s before the start of the substance application.
The average afferent arteriole diameter in the live slice model was 7.34 Ϯ 0.29 m (n ϭ 51) under control conditions.
Before extensive ANG II experiments, an ANG II CRC (10 Ϫ10 to 10 Ϫ6 M) was constructed to estimate the concentration of expected maximal response (Fig. 3C).
ANG II 10 Ϫ7 M was chosen as it produced an arteriolar constriction suitable for a potential left or right shift under hypoxia.
Moreover, the measured response to ANG II (10 Ϫ7 M) in the CRC corresponds to the constriction measured after bolus application of ANG II (10 Ϫ7 M) (44.55 Ϯ 2.01 vs. 44.49
Effect of ANG II is NO modulated.
To assess the influence of NO on the ANG II-induced constriction, slices were incubated with the NOS-inhibitor L-NAME (10 Ϫ4 M).
The baseline diameter of afferent arterioles was not significantly altered by the pretreatment with L-NAME (7.13 Ϯ 0.48 m before L-NAME vs. 6.80 Ϯ 0.45 m after L-NAME pretreatment; n ϭ 8).
Blocking NOS and simultaneously applying ANG II (10 Ϫ7 M) resulted in a significantly enhanced constriction of afferent arterioles compared with ANG II alone (32.25 Ϯ 2.34%; n ϭ 8; Fig. 3B).

Since the duration of hypoxia as well as reoxygenation may influence cellular signaling systems and generation of metabolites, which in turn may affect arteriolar tone and reactivity, we varied the duration of hypoxia and reoxygenation periods.
Generally, the combination of H/R and ANG II application caused a significantly increased constriction of afferent arterioles compared with control conditions (Fig. 4).
In this study, a maximal constriction was reached after 90 min of hypoxia and a reoxygenation period of 20 min (25.90
Ϯ 1.99% of baseline diameter; n ϭ 8).
Reoxygenation of 10 min did not provoke significant differences in the maximal constriction following ANG II treatment when comparing vessels with a 30-, 60-, and 90-min hypoxia duration (Fig. 4A).
However, with the application of 20 min of reoxygenation, the constriction increases in proportion to the time of hypoxia.
Afferent arterioles displayed significantly increased constriction after 90 min of hypoxia compared with 30 min (Fig. 4B; 39.73 Ϯ 4.09 vs. 25.90

div.head: Isolated afferent arterioles showed increased ANG II-induced dose-dependent constrictions following H/R.

p.s: To investigate the mechanisms of increased reactivity to ANG II after H/R, we stepped back to the model of isolated vessels.
Figure 2, C and D, illustrates changes in the luminal diameter of isolated perfused afferent arterioles following ANG II application.
CRCs were obtained by application of ANG II (10 Ϫ12 to 10 Ϫ6 M; n ϭ 8).
ANG II constricted afferent arterioles in a concentration-dependent manner, with a maximal response of 67% (Fig. 5A).
H/R significantly increased the response to ANG II (10 Ϫ9 M) and significantly shifted log EC 50 to the left (EC 50 control: 1.49 ϫ 10 Ϫ9 M vs. EC 50 H/R: 9.86 ϫ 10 Ϫ10 M;
HYPOXIA-REOXYGENATION INCREASES VASOCONSTRICTION P ϭ 0.04), if compared with control conditions.
Thus isolated arterioles showed a strengthening effect of H/R on the ANG II reactivity.
The increased ANG II response following H/R is blunted after preincubation with the SOD mimetic TEMPOL (10 Ϫ4 M) (Fig. 5B).
The cytosolic calcium concentrations, as measured using fura-2, revealed similar ANG II induced changes in the ratio 340/380 nm for controls and for vessels subjected to H/R (Fig. 5C; n ϭ 8).
ANG II receptor mRNA expression is not altered after H/R.
MRNA levels were measured in iron oxide perfusion-isolated renal arterioles.

After 1 h of hypoxia, we were not able to detect differences in mRNA expression of ANG II type 1a receptor (AT 1a R), ANG II type 1b receptor (AT 1b R), and ANG II type 2 receptor (AT 2 R), if compared with control conditions (Fig. 6A).
H/R regulates NADPH oxidase mRNA expression in afferent arterioles.
NADPH oxidase enzymes NOX1, NOX2, NOX4, and their regulatory subunits p47phox and p67phox are expressed in the vasculature and differentially expressed following H/R.
H/R treatment resulted in a significant upregulation of NOX2, p47phox, and p67phox and a significant downregulation of the potentially vasoprotective NOX4 in isolated afferent arterioles (Fig. 6B).
H/R decreased SOD activity in live kidney slices.
To analyze the role of superoxide radicals for the increased ANG II response after H/R, SOD activity was measured in live slices.
Activity was analyzed after control and H/R (30-20 and 90-20) treatment.
To achieve consistent analysis, the results are given as SOD unit/mg protein.
SOD activity was significantly de-creased following hypoxia of 90 min and reoxygenation of 20 min compared with control conditions (Fig. 7).
In this study, we have shown that H/R significantly increased ANG II responses of afferent arterioles in a live kidney slice model and in isolated arterioles.
We have further observed a dependency of vasoconstriction on the duration of reoxygenation following extended hypoxia.

Results from isolated afferent arterioles indicated that H/R could be associated with increased expression of NOX2 and its regulatory subunits, decreased NOX4 expression, and increased calcium sensitivity.
Interestingly, an influence of tubules on vasoreactivity was not detectable.
Our findings indicate that enhanced vasoreactivity following H/R might be one component in the multifactorial genesis of AKI.
This study further supports the previously proposed interplay of oxidative stress and ANG II leading to increased vasoconstriction.
To test the in situ model, slice viability and responses to exogenously applied vasoactive substances under control conditions were determined.
Previously published histology scoring systems of kidney injury refer to in vivo settings (21,24) and are not adequate for analysis of acute experiments in kidney slices.
Therefore, we used hematoxylin and eosin staining for an overall estimation of slice viability and classified the slice damage into a simple, qualitative system of three categories.
No damage of cortical structures was detectable in live slices under control conditions up to 90 min.
After H/R, mild (30 min) and severe (90 min) damage was found in terms of
AT1bR AT2R relative x-fold mRNA expression coagulative necrosis, a typical aspect of IRI, and slight cellular swelling.
Therefore, we rule out a significant tissue damage and conclude that tissue integrity is preserved for an investigation period of 90 min.

Previous studies, using established models such as isolated vessels and the preparation of juxtamedullary nephrons, showed agonist-provoked constriction in response to ANG II (25,42), NE (6) and ET-1 (43).
These vasoactive substances play key roles in renal perfusion and vessel function, especially considering their upregulation in the ischemic and postischemic phase (22).
ANG II is locally and systemically active, and its inhibition improves renal function following IRI (19,25).
Tubules are a major source of vasoactive substances in the renal cortex and medulla.
During hypoxic injury, the generation and secretion of, e.g., ANG II, ET-1, or adenosine might be altered and might therefore significantly influence arteriolar function.
The in situ model offers the advantage of tubules surrounding the arterioles, which allows the investigation of a potential tubular influence (11).
We therefore determined the response of afferent arterioles to the well-investigated and physiologically important agonists ANG II, NE, ET-1, and ATP under control conditions.
The observed constrictions of afferent arterioles correspond to that of isolated, perfused afferent arterioles (13,20,26,27,44).
NO and ANG II are important modulators of renal vascular tone (14,37,39).
Oxidative stress that develops after reperfusion injury provokes a diminished bioavailability of NO (1,2,14), which could further lead to enhanced arteriolar constriction.
In this study, we aimed to test to what extent NO antagonizes ANG II-induced vasoconstriction under control conditions.
We approached this situation by using the NOSinhibitor L-NAME.
The basal tone of afferent arterioles remained unchanged by L-NAME application.
Assumingly, a relevant production of NO in the basal state is lacking, which was already described in mouse afferent arterioles (35).
A subsequent ANG II application significantly decreased the lumen diameter of afferent arterioles.
This indicates that the slices can release L-NAME-inhibitable NO under control conditions, despite the lack of constant perfusion.
It further points to previously discussed local vasodilatory mechanisms that may counteract potentially harmful ANG II-induced vasoconstriction.
It was proposed recently that ANG II balances its own constrictor action in afferent arterioles by a negative feedback mechanism that activates NO release very likely via its AT 1 R (35,40,41).
Activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone following ischemia-reperfusion contributes to AKI (30).
Via its AT 1 R, ANG II exerts most known effects of this system, including renal vasoconstriction.
Remarkably, ANG II-but not NE-or ET-1-induced constriction of larger renal arteries is sensitive to stress conditions such as H/R (23,34).
Therefore, we tested the hypothesis that H/R enhances renal microvessel constriction to ANG II, thus contributing to impaired renal perfusion.

We observed that longer periods of hypoxia go along with stronger ANG II-induced arteriolar constriction only after an increased reoxygenation period of 20 min but remain steady increased after a 10-min reoxygenation.
ROS release and scavenging of NO during reoxygenation may explain this observation (3,14).
In this context, local activation of ANG II during IRI has been shown to activate NADPH oxidase (15,16), a major source of ROS.
Our results using the superoxide dismutase mimetic TEMPOL confirm the previous findings.
Preincubation with TEMPOL reduced the vasoconstrictive response to ANG II following H/R pointing to an important role of ROS in this setup.

To further dissect the mechanism by which H/R modifies the constrictor response to ANG II in this model, we studied calcium transients, ANG II receptors, SOD activity, and NADPH oxidase expression levels.

Noteably, there was no difference in the ANG II-induced cytosolic calcium when comparing control and H/R conditions, suggesting that not the calcium pathway, but calcium-sensitizing mechanisms, are involved in the short-term H/R effect.
Furthermore, in our study, ANG II receptors in isolated vessels showed no significantly different expression.
This indicates that regulation of AT 1a R, AT 1b R, and AT 2 R levels is not responsible for the observed ANG II effects under H/R.
In line with this finding is a study by Kontogiannis and Burns (25), who could not detect differences in cortical AT 1 R mRNA expression after ischemia-reperfusion (25).
The NADPH oxidase isoforms NOX1, NOX2, and NOX4 were found in the vasculature, of which NOX4 has been reported to be vasoprotective (12).
In contrast, NOX1 and NOX2 promote endothelial dysfunction in various disease models via scavenging of NO by O 2 Ϫ (8, 12, 31, 45).
We found significantly increased NOX2 and significantly decreased NOX4 mRNA expression levels following H/R indicating a change in ROS production after 60 min of hypoxia.
Previously, a significant increase of NOX activity was reported already after 5 min of acute hypoxia in pulmonary arteries (38).
Moreover, the observed reduction in SOD activity following H/R indicates increased ROS availability and might be responsible for the enhanced vasoconstriciton.
It is still unresolved to what extent surrounding tissue influences vasoreactivity following H/R.
We therefore compared ANG II-induced vasoconstriction of isolated vessels under H/R treatment with that found in in situ experiments.
In both settings, H/R augmented afferent arteriolar responses to ANG II.
Thus H/R affects afferent arteriolar function independently of the surrounding tubules.

The different application methods (bolus application in slices vs. concentration-re- sponse-curve in isolated arterioles) and the different oxygen pressures in the control groups hamper a quantitative comparison of the impact of H/R, but there is an enhancing effect of ANG II responses seen in both models.
Moreover, our recent unpublished data showed that switching from 95% to 21% O 2 had no effect on vessel function.
In conclusion, we show that the investigation of contractile function of afferent arterioles is feasible in live kidney slices.

The influence of the tubuli and the surrounding tissue on the H/R-induced increased ANG II responses of afferent arterioles appears neglectable, which suggests that the mechanism of the strengthening of the contractile response to ANG II is located in the vessel itself.
Calcium sensitivity and ROS production seem to be important for the increased response to ANG II after H/R.
REOXYGENATION INCREASES VASOCONSTRICTIONAfferent arterioles constricted in response to ANG II (10 Ϫ7 M), NE (10 Ϫ5 M), ET-1 (10 Ϫ7 M), and ATP (10 Ϫ4 M) (Fig.3A).
The diameter reduced to 44.49
Fig. 1.
Histological analysis of live kidney slices.
A-C: representative histological images of renal cortex hematoxylin and eosin paraffin sections (ϫ400) depicting qualitative assessment of hypoxia-reoxygenation (H/R)-induced damage.
Slices treated with carbogen for up to 90 min showed no tissue damage (A).
Following H/R, slices were mildly (B; 30-min H/R) or severely (C; 90-min H/R) damaged as visible by necrotic loss of nuclei staining and loss of tissue integrity.
Fig.3.
Analysis of functional response of afferent arterioles in living kidney slices under control conditions.

A: effect of bolus application of ANG II (10 Ϫ7 M) (n ϭ 10), norepinephrine (NE; 10 Ϫ5 M) (n ϭ 8), endothelin-1 (ET-1; 10 Ϫ7 M) (n ϭ 6) and ATP (10 Ϫ4 M) (n ϭ 6), respectively, on afferent arteriolar diameter.
Plotted is the respective maximum constriction in %baseline diameter.
B: effect of the nitric oxide synthase (NOS) inhibitor N G -nitro-L-arginine methyl ester (L-NAME; 10 Ϫ4 M) (n ϭ 8) on the ANG II-induced vasoconstriction.
Plotted is the respective maximum constriction following a bolus application of ANG II (10 Ϫ7 M) in %baseline diameter.
The afferent arteriolar diameter is significantly decreased following ANG II and L-NAME treatment.
A and B: the same data for ANG II-induced constriction.
Data are given as mean Ϯ SE. **P Ͻ 0.01 by Mann-Whitney test.
C: ANG II concentration response curve (CRC) under control conditions in afferent arterioles in living kidney slices (n ϭ 6).
The CRC was produced to identify an efficient ANG II bolus concentration for the following functional H/R experiments.
Fig.5.
Analysis of isolated afferent arterioles under control and H/R conditions.
A: ANG II CRC after control conditions and after H/R (60/10 min) (n ϭ 8).
H/R significantly shifted log EC50 to the left (EC50: control 1.49 ϫ 10 -9 M vs. H/R 9.86 ϫ 10 -10 M; P ϭ 0.04) as analyzed with Mann-Whitney rank sum test.
B: ANG II CRC in the presence of TEMPOL (n ϭ 6).
C: effect of hypoxia on ANG II-induced intracellular calcium transients.
The change of the calcium ratio was measured as the fura-2 340/380 ratio.
The appropriate ANG II-induced changes are similar under hypoxic and control conditions (n ϭ 8).
"Basal" corresponds to the baseline measurement before the start of ANG II CRC.
Data are given as means Ϯ SE.
Fig.7.
Effect of H/R on superoxide dismutase (SOD) activity in live kidney slices.
All 3 types of SOD were measured; 1 unit is defined as the amount of enzyme needed to exhibit 50% dismutation of superoxide radicals generated by xanthine oxidase and hypoxanthine.
SOD activity was significantly reduced following H/R (90-20) if compared with control conditions.
Data are given as means Ϯ SE (n ϭ 7-8).
*P Ͻ 0.05, compared with control as analyzed by the Mann-Whitney test.
List and sequences of primers used for mRNA expression analysis
AT1aR, ANG II type 1a receptor; AT1bR, ANG II type 1b receptor; AT2R, ANG II type 2 receptor; NOX, NADPH oxidase enzyme.
